I.  THE WOMEN’S FINANCING MARKETPLACE 
 
1.  The REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s Financing Marketplace, approved in 
November 2020, will facilitate and broaden access to finance for women and women businesses 
and communicate ADB’s efforts in this area to encourage more lending to this sector.1 Many 
financial institutions (FIs) in ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) have not targeted 
women borrowers and do not recognize the untapped commercial potential.2  Moreover, there is 
a lack of awareness of the barriers women or women businesses encounter when trying to access 
financial  services.  Therefore,  there  is  an  absence  of  targeted  marketing  and  suitable  and 
affordable products for women. The impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic 
have reinforced the importance of a digital economy to change business models into digital 
business  models  and  to  integrate  digital  channels  into  how  financial  service  providers  or 
businesses engage with customers. 
 
2.  During this period and post-COVID-19 under the “new normal” environment, a dedicated 
online platform can help support FIs and their existing and potential women borrowers. The 
Women’s Financing Marketplace (the Marketplace) is an innovative approach using a digital 
platform to interact with and engage through social media channels to build a subscriber base 
and follower list that will be used to facilitate an online community through linkages and resources 
on content relevant for the FIs and their female borrowers. The Marketplace will: (i) aggregate 
and disseminate products on gender financing in the financial sector within ADB and to the 
broader external audience; (ii) support the identification of cutting-edge technologies for FIs to 
achieve operational efficiencies, develop and scale new products to digitize business models, 
such as the use of alternative credit scoring models, mobile technology, cloud technology, and 
online delivery channels; (iii) build capacity for FIs to promote gender responsive financial service 
delivery and women businesses to improve viability through a range of digital toolkits, webinars 
and online support; (iv) establish linkages to other programs and initiatives on enabling access to 
finance for women, internal and external to ADB3; and (v) create a community platform to attract 
other  co-financiers,  including  potential  technical  assistance  (TA)  funding  providers.  The 
identification of innovative technologies for service delivery models will be supported through this 
TA, Subproject 2. 
 
3.  The TA cluster is envisaged to have 4 Subprojects: (i) Design, Set up and Maintenance of 
the Marketplace, (ii) Innovation and Technologies, (iii) Capacity Building, and (iv) Expansion of 
the Marketplace. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
4.  This is the second subproject under the REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s 
Financing Marketplace. The first subproject was approved in November 2020 and consultants are 
being recruited. 
 
 
1  Women business in this context means micro-, small- and medium-sized women-owned or women-managed 
businesses. 
2  Financial institutions in this context are banks and non-bank financial institutions including microfinance institutions, 
housing finance, and insurance companies, for instance. 
3  For example, PSFI’s Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program or ADB Ventures and SDCC’s Gender 
and Development initiatives or Tech for Impact.

2 
B.  Subproject Scope  
 
5.  The TA cluster has the following overall outcome: sustainable financial inclusion for 
women and women businesses increased. Subproject 2 will specifically contribute by supporting 
the identification and design of innovative technologies and suitable and sustainable digital 
service delivery models to support gender-responsive ecosystems. 
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
 
6.  Output 1: Innovative technologies designed to support digital gender-responsive 
ecosystems.  Many FIs and women’s businesses in ADB’s DMCs have not yet digitized their 
service delivery models. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need to face the challenge 
of digital transformation and ADB will seek to support FIs and women businesses in addressing 
this opportunity.4 FIs will be identified and selected based on specific criteria, among others their 
need for digitization of business processes, their focus on  increasing finance to women’s 
businesses, and their management’s buy-in for the digital transformation. In the first phase, one 
such activity, as provided under this subproject, will be to conduct a market scoping and needs 
assessment for innovative financial technologies relevant for FIs that intend to increase their 
gender-responsive finance portfolio. These would be specific technologies that facilitate greater 
access to finance for women or women’s businesses. This can be done in cooperation with one 
FI or several FIs in a specific country or region or on a stand-alone basis. Based on the 
assessment, an FI can be supported through ADB’s technology platform to identify suitable 
cutting-edge digital solutions for “last mile” service delivery targeted to women’s businesses with 
the potential to pilot such solutions.5 This would, for example, address issues such as a lack of 
infrastructure and connectivity, challenges of remote locations, efficiency and cost factors and 
gender disparities. The first FI to be supported will be in Papua New Guinea (PNG) as the 
cofinancing is earmarked for PNG. In PNG, this component can then also build on ADB’s 
sovereign sector experience of supporting the Bank of PNG in the creation of a national digital ID, 
ADB’s partnership with a local FI, and its sovereign programs targeting the development of small 
and medium-sized enterprises, with a specific focus on women.  
 
7.  In addition, support can also be provided directly to an FI through IT assessments as well 
as capacity building for specific gender lens financing topics and digital solutions such as, for 
example, alternative credit scoring models which incorporate gender specific data.6 This could be 
in the form of digitizing credit scoring models or integrating gender-specific data in the algorithms. 
Monitoring of the FI and evaluating the results from this work will also be a necessary part of the 
process to assess the impact of these initiatives. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
8.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $400,000, of which all will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (WeFi) under the Women Accelerating 
 
4  First, focus will be on supporting FIs which are already ADB clients or potential new clients and have contacted ADB 
for support. The next phase will cover individual women’s businesses as well. 
5  This will be done in cooperation with ADB’s Information Technology Department. See challenges.adb.org or 
digital.adb.org. 
6  In cooperation with the FI, it can be decided whether ADB’s support comes in the form of consulting services, support 
through hackathon or sandbox programs or contribution to the FI’s own assessment, preparation, and implementation 
of new technologies. Cost matching from the FI will be sought as much as possible.

3 
Vibrant Enterprises in Southeast Asia and the Pacific (WAVES) program.7 The funds will support, 
among  others,  the  identification  of  cutting-edge  technology  solutions  for  digital,  gender- 
responsive financial service delivery in a safe environment with a potential to commercially pilot 
such solutions. It will cover IT infrastructure (as necessary), remuneration, travel, and per diem 
for international/national consultants and miscellaneous expenses. ADB will seek cost-matching 
from its client as much as possible. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
9.  ADB will administer Subproject 2 and its Private Sector Operations Department, Financial 
Institutions Division, will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants in collaboration with the 
Transaction Support Division and Information Technology Department, as necessary.

10.  Consulting services. Individual consultants (national/international) will be recruited by 
PSOD/PSFI in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and the associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. A firm may 
also be recruited using the quality and cost-based selection method in accordance with the ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time). A single-source selection may also be 
considered,  subject to  required  approvals,  should  specific  expertise  be  required.  Shopping 
procedures may be used as appropriate. The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are 
indicative, and estimates will be finalized prior to advertisement. 8 Output based and/or lump-sum 
contracts will be considered but time-based contracts will be used, as appropriate. 
 
 
7  The Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative is a groundbreaking partnership that aims to unlock financing for 
women-led and women-owned businesses in developing countries. We-Fi’s partners include 14 donor governments, 
six multilateral development banks as implementing partners, and numerous other stakeholders in the public and 
private sector around the world. 
8  As applicable, fixed out-of-pocket expenses, for administrative efficiency and to simplify the disbursement process 
will be used.
